frontmatter.title: Homelab 101
frontmatter.author: Nate Wood
frontmatter.excerpt: An intro to homelab - what is it and why you should have one

markdownRemark.html:
What is a homelab?

It's a collection of computer hardware and software typically used for learning or self-hosting

Why build a homelab?

  • Learning experience outside of school or work
  • Can help with getting a job
  • It's fun!

What can I do with it?

  • Learn to use or administer new operating systems/equipment

    • Linux distributions like Ubuntu, CentOS, or Kali
    • Windows Server and related services like Active Directory or certificate management
    • Networking and firewall
    • Virtualization platforms such as ESXi, ProxMox, Hyper-V
    • Container technology like Docker, Kuberneties

  • Run enterprise grade hardware or software

    • Many enterprise software suites have a community edition available

  • Run a game server for your friends

    • The dedicated host will allow you to not use your own resource running the game locally

  • Media server

    • Host your own digital library of home movies and photos with friends and family

  • Storage server

    • Who needs DropBox or Google Drive if you have your own cloud file hosting service

  • Web hosting

    • Host your own blog or services

Is it expensive?

It doesn't have to be - but if you're anything like myself you will eventually spend more money on the homelab :)

Hardware

  • You don't need to have a full server rack to be able to take advantage of a homelab
  • A Rasberry Pi or similar is sufficient to run a small Linux server or host
  • Start small and let it grow into an uncontrollable hobby :D

What about the cloud?

Cloud providers typically provide free use for a short period of time - take full advantage of the free compute and storage if you can.

  • AWS – 12 months
  • Azure – 12 months - $200 to spend in first 30 days
  • Google Compute – 12 months - $300 credit with new accounts

Software

There are lots of options available for open source or free to use (community editions) of homelab related software. Below is a short list of what might be good to look into.

  • Hypervisor

    • ESXi, ProxMox, Hyper-V, VMWare Workstation, Oracle VirtualBox

  • Networking

    • Sophos UTM, Pfsense, PiHole

  • Operating Systems

    • Microsoft, Linux (too many to list)

  • Storage

    • FreeNAS, Nextcloud, unRAID

  • Monitoring

    • ELK stack, Graylog, QRadar CE, Splunk CE

  • Configuration Management

    • Salt, Ansible, Puppet
  • Media
  • Plex, Kodi

  • Misc.

    • phpIPAM, Grafana, misc development tools ()

Cost of the homelab

  • Sleepless nights figuring out why your server broke
  • S.O. / kids upset about power/lights/sound/cost of the homelab
  • Hardware (not required)
  • Electric bill

How to build a homelab

  • Decide what you want to do and where you're going to run it

  • Start tinkering!

  • Document the process - either in a blog, GitHub, or personal notes

    • Network diagrams are nice too

Resources

  • Reddit.com : Homelab wiki
  • Opensource.com: How to set up a homelab from hardware to firewall
  • Hackernoon.com: The Open Home Lab Stack
  • e5.onthehub.com: Free licenses for students
